Let me be clear: the transparency framework is not a perfect measure. We're not assessing the quality of evidence. Additionally, if the evidence behind a policy can't be found, it doesn‚Äôt mean that the evidence doesn‚Äôt exist or that it wasn‚Äôt considered in policy-making.

(5) Biological determinants must be taken as seriously as social, behavioural, structural & environmental determinants.  No one has primacy over the other.  The failure of many PH practitioners to embrace the biological is detrimental to modern PH practice

(4) PH practitioners must embrace a paradigm that allows both social & biological models of disease to be used in their preventive strategies.  The narrative that these are competing strategies must cease.

(3) In the era of personalised health care the interaction of genetic & non-genetic factors is fundamental to the understanding of effective disease prevention. The reality at which these meet is the individual organism.

(2) Moreover, biology works through individuals. The impact of social and structural factors affect individuals & their individual lives. Populations are no more than sets of individuals.  Individuals are real. Populations are a social construction - albeit a very useful one.

(1) PH has always had two complementary strategies for disease prevention. These may focus on the population or on high risk groups & their roles were amply discussed by the great Geoffrey Rose. Precision PH is no more or no less than an extension of the high risk approach

I often think about this interaction when I encounter folks with uncompromising positions on a range of issues I care about. These people are needed, but so are those working toward change within the constraints of the ‚Äúreal world‚Äù.

His point being, look, I‚Äôm one of the most angry leftists out there. I‚Äôve spent my life holding people in power to account and advocating for change. But I still know that modest progress is better than no progress, or worse, regression. And modest progress accumulates.
One of his quotes I found online says it better: ‚ÄúIt makes sense to work towards a better world, but it doesn't make any sense to have illusions about what the real world is.‚Äù
When question time came, someone asked why Chomsky, an anarchist, was supporting a mainstream (albeit left-wing) political candidate.Chomsky‚Äôs reply: ‚ÄúBecause I live in the real world.‚Äù

10/ As validators of the system, the DAO will run as PoS validators and earn the utility token on the Gateway, GTC.
9/ Anyone with the DAO token (GATE) can become a member of the DAO. You can acquire 1 GATE by locking 10 CTC.
8/ The Gateway DAO fills the gap. Anyone can ask to move their assets across the bridge or propose to expand to a new blockchain. The decentralized DAO will approve.
7/ We also want a decentralized bridge. If the process is centralized, it defeats the purpose of using blockchain in the first place.
6/ We want the bridge to be expandable, reaching out to any new upcoming blockchain. In an ever-changing market, adaptability is critical.

This low-cost low-input technique has a lot of potential to improve genomics workflows. It is suitable for many applications including ChIP-Seq and degraded samples. We have applied for Japanese patent on this technique and are open to discuss licensing for commercial use.

There are a few caveats. BrAD-Seq generally had poorer sequence quality in Read 2. We don‚Äôt recommend paired end sequencing with this technique but it is compatible with it if required (as it is for some sequencing facilities).

We show that BrAD-Seq has lower GC bias and has high library complexity in plant genomes with a low average GC content. This is a significant advantage to avoid issues with GC rich bacterial samples as well. https://t.co/vILzdhHH7e

We demonstrate that BrAD-Seq has less bias towards multi-copy plastics genomes. More reads map to the largest chromosomes as we expect. Low input libraries have similar results. https://t.co/yYxkq1145P

We compared BrAD-Seq to several popular kits for low-input amounts. We show that BrAD-Seq produced good quality libraries with high coverage breadth in both Arabidopsis and Drosophila samples. https://t.co/9VO8jPAAWv

This technique is very cost effective. We are able to get similar quality libraries at a fraction of the cost of commercially available kits. This could open the door to many studies not otherwise feasible. https://t.co/G1LXJYdSIS

Pleased to share our work from on BrAD-Seq a technique for genomic DNA library preparation. We demonstrate a new method for fast, low-cost library preparation with low-input amounts.#genomics #ngs@riken_en @RIKEN_IMS @riken_brc_jp    https://t.co/mFDz0uclV3

If you'd like to ask me questions about the review process, or give comments on what I've written, feel free to reply here. Bear in mind that there are confidentiality agreements in place (mostly around identifiability), so I may not be able to answer all questions.NgƒÅ mihi.
I end my writeup with a few bits of general advice for people applying for funding:* read the guidelines* make it obvious* expect a distracted reviewer* be sensitive to importance* show the result
This cannot fully substitute the experience of submitting an application, but hopefully it can provide new researchers with a bit more information to help level the playing field.

In 2021, I was given the opportunity to participate in an HRC review panel. I wrote about my experience so that applicants who are new to HRC application submission can get a better idea about what is behind the review process.

YMMV, but one of the most striking things about leaving academia for me was how working on the weekend stopped feeling like a normal thing to do
but your personal choice to work every weekend (or not) doesn't just affect you - it also affects the culture/norms of your workplace
outside of the (obviously toxic) cases where a PI will e.g. tell people they are required to work every weekend, students/postdocs who work 60+ hours a week generally *are* choosing to do so.

We should ... be proud of what we've built, and yet know there is so much more. Biology - molecular biology - is the science of this century I am sure - and it's foundations are based on shared data and knowledge.

It is an impressive city of data and knowledge. It takes real dedication to make each wall, each house and to keep it up to date (many of those dedicated people work in the institute I am part of, @emblebi, but other institutes bring this all together).

And the raw data, through transform, through knowledge has to be made searchable and accessible, ideally with the least amount of foreknowledge needed of what could be interesting or where one needs to look.

These transforms reconcile, bridge and infer from multiple points some biological understanding, itself a somewhat moving target (for example, small translated open reading frames - what should we ... call them? are they important? how should they be represented?)

Those datasets though are often exhausting to use and reconcile, so many of these databases transform data using either human neurons in people's brains (curators) or human programming skills to run analysis methods (bioinformaticians; data scientists in molecular biology)

The data must be deposited and collected with just the right amount of meta-data to be useful and not so much to be a burden. These datasets have to be aggregated and linked to other datasets and publications - the narrative of why and how of the scientist who collected them.
But these final edifices of molecular biology knowledge, always growing like some city of knowledge growing higher and wider are complex to build and maintain.

Theories and working models in molecular biology lie between datasets, like the mortar of a brick wall, to bridge one dataset to the next; the molecular theory of evolution couldn't predict the human genome from the mouse (or ancestral primate), but it can bridge these datasets.

Biology - molecular biology in particular - has to be rendered into individual data and then knowledge items to be useful. We might have theories in molecular biology, such as evolution, or established working models, such as DNA->RNA->Protein but these are rarely predictive

The table of contents has some long lived parts of this library, such as the Protein Databank (PDB) rubbing shoulders with the new and trendy stuff, sometimes in the same field (AlphaFoldDB) sometimes completely different (Echinoderm database for the win!)

Browsing the Nucleic Acid Research database issue (https://t.co/QFj6EDlfvm) is a joy of just the complexity of molecular biology and how to understand it ultimately data, information and knowledge has be in computational form - the modern library of Alexandria for biology.

DNA is not your destiny, it is just the cards you were born with. You (and your parents and all of us in how we structure society) get to choose how to play this game.
And both of these go to *using* genetics - for understanding and for improving screening - not thinking of genetics as some sort of modern day "fate" or "astrology".

We should ... just do this. Or, at the very least, get *way* better at cascade testing from established probands (I believe the Netherlands do this well, less so UK). And then rinse and repeat around more places, careful to understand screening and intervention benefit/harms.

The second thing is stressing that there are some diseases (eg atherlosceloris) where we have good screening methods (LDL levels) and safe interventions (statins) that we can leverage genetic prediction (rare, such as LDLR or common)

This sort of intermediate phenotype "trace through" analysis is in this whole soup of causal effect tracing, which leverages both single variants, multiple variants (MR techniques) and full fat polygenic risk scores, with the goal to understand, ultimately, aetiology of disease.

But at the same time the genetics adds two things - firstly for each disease endpoint we can break down the components (look at Type II diabetes vs Hb1ac) and understand perhaps more which pathway is leading to burden

At some level this paper is mainly "obvious" - these disease are the major burdens in the western world, common and rare genetic variation underlies some of the variation in biology that changes the risk to these diseases, and indeed we see this play out here.

But encountering other people who you think should know better, doing rather foolish indoor things with high potential for COVID exposure, just feels so so frustrating.Two of their older extended family members are currently sick with COVID to boot! /8

Like, I realize we are privileged. I am able to WFH, able to support us on 1 income, and SO homeschools our kids. All who can be vaccinated are. I'm trying to do everything right when it comes to protecting my family. /7

In addition, our church currently meets in person, without any distancing or mask mandates, and the choir has restarted. I see only a few masks being worn on livestream.But a pastor noted last Sunday that 20+ families are currently suffering w/ COVID. /6 https://t.co/HVGbOu9jBg

But then I recall all of the personal stories so many have shared on here of what it is like for even a "mild" non-hospitalized case of COVID, and how hospitals are faring, and seeing the daily COVID numbers at the hospital I work for. /5

I know my kids really enjoy playing and interacting w/ them, and my SO really needs the human contact w/ someone outside the house.But it's stressing me out, and making me question if the risk mitigation we've been doing personally is even worth it? /4

Recently, I've been seeing that other family, at least the MD father (neurologist, FWIW), taking the kids to indoor, un-masked events, including their 2 yo adopted daughter.And I don't know if I want to keep meeting w/ them inside? /3

We really only go out to get groceries and doc visits that *can't* be done telehealth or there is a huge advantage in person (speech therapy for 3 being one of those), my SO has 1 friend over regularly for coffee, and kids play w/ one other family inside. /2

Also a heartfelt thank you to the many colleagues who collected the samples, sequenced the viral genomes and shared them on GISAID.12/

The work was single-handedly driven by @cedriccstan, in collaboration with many wonderful colleagues, with a special mention to @LucyvanDorp and the amazing Pen State crew (Meera, Suresh and Kapur).11/

This work is an update on previous analyses with improved methods and a larger number of genomes analysed. We also teamed up with colleagues from Penn State who sequenced 96% of the available SARSCoV2 genomes from white-tailed deer.10/

Though, based on the current evidence, viral strains making  a detour through an animal reservoir are not expected to transmit better in humans, to be more virulent or better at escaping immune recognition.9/
The results suggest that spill-back events of SARSCoV2 from animal reservoirs into humans are to be anticipated. This has already happened with mink in Denmark (before they were all culled).8/

Taken together, our results suggest that minimal adaptation was required for human-to-animal spillover and subsequent onward transmission in mink and deer, highlighting the ‚Äògeneralist‚Äô nature of SARS-CoV-2 as a pathogen readily infecting a wide number of mammals.7/

All in all, circulation of SARS-CoV-2 in mink and deer has caused only moderate changes to the evolutionary trajectory of SARS-CoV-2 thus far. We also do not observe evidence for accelerated evolution in animals (i.e. higher mutation rate).6/ https://t.co/OuGd8lU2ah

We identified six candidate mutations for animal-specific adaptation in mink (NSP9_G37E, Spike_F486L, Spike_N501T, Spike_Y453F, ORF3a_T229I, ORF3a_L219V), and one in deer (NSP3a_L1035F). None of those mutations is expected to increase viral fitness in humans.5/ https://t.co/pXkhH4WvUS

We searched for candidate mutations associated to host jumps, and for those that may emerge and rise in frequency after the host jump. No mutations seems required for a host jump into mink/deer, but some mutations show evidence for positive selection once in mink/deer . 4/ https://t.co/qSeaxBBSnw

We found a minimum of 24 and 20 distinct clusters of SARSCoV2 in mink and deer caused by independent spillover events of viral strains circulating in humans. Subsequent animal-to-animal transmission may lead the virus to adapt to its new host.3/

Essentially any SARSCoV2 lineage seems equally likely to infect dogs, cats, lions/tigers, mink and deer. Host jumps into cats and dogs are dead ends. Dogs do not  transmit well and domestic cats don't have much opportunity to infect other cats, and zoo animals are a bit stuck.2/

Spillover events of SARSCoV2 from humans to animals have been reported for many species, including mink, white-tailed deer, dogs, as well as small and big cats (lions, tigers). We looked for SARSCoV2 genomic adaptations to transmission in animals. 1/https://t.co/R5go8I46pK https://t.co/UsEFV0PdIS

Summing up:1. Don't let peer pressure trick you into thinking academia is the default best option for you.2. Think parallel, not serial, when considering career options.3. Gather information, contacts, and diverse mentors early.4. Good luck!

Know that when you talk to fellow academics about exploring non-academic career options, they may struggle to understand why. You may feel like actively looking outside is a signal that you aren't good enough for academia.Fuck that noise. This is your life, not theirs.

I'm not going to pretend these decisions are easy - at every inflection point in my career I've agonised over making a call - but your odds of a good outcome are much higher, because you haven't arbitrarily constrained the field.

The value of this model is you get to consider every opportunity on its merits. You may find an industry option that is better on every dimension than all your academic offers. You may find an academic option where flexibility/optionality outweighs salary concerns.

If everything goes well, you will find yourself with multiple opportunities, inside and outside academia. Consider all of them on their merits, and make the choice the best suits you, and that maximises your future options.

This is so important because different types of opportunity require very different approaches. Don't be fooled into thinking an industry employer will value the same things your academic colleagues do. Prepare yourself and your CV accordingly.

In the lead-up to this, you should be talking to mentors from the full spectrum of these roles. Don't just talk to your supervisor about careers. Seek out and find mentors from other backgrounds, people who actually know what a non-academic career is like.

When you get towards the end of your PhD, your plan shouldn't be to apply for postdoc positions, then *if unsuccessful* start applying for industry roles. You want to be considering (and ideally applying for) jobs across the full range of careers that would suit you.

So here's my advice on a career mindset for young academics: forget the serial model, and go parallel.Figure out what you're good at, and what you enjoy.Determine the full range of careers consistent with these parameters, and investigate all of them. https://t.co/ySSVEdAc6W

Vax effectiveness (against death) is composed of a) protection against getting infected and b) protection against death once infected.The ~90-95% we got for mRNA vax pre-Omicron included a) and b).Here, only b) was estimated. 3/

This was all pre-Omicron, even pre-Delta. The numbers are likely quite a lot worse for people who were infected a year ago and haven't gotten vaccinated since.One needs to be careful to not compare the numbers directly with vax effectiveness: 2/

We take a deep dive into WBOs and a POC for using them to interpolated torsion force constants. Using this approach we can potentially reduce the number of QM torsion scans needed and get better torsion parameters for conjugated bonds. (8/8)

We also find that when we look at how the changes in WBO w.r.t. conformations are correlated across bonds, the structure of the conjugated systems are evident in the correlation plots. (7/8) https://t.co/kTKyzPpdMk

In addition to looking at how we can use WBOs to fit torsion parameters, this manuscript also includes a detailed study of WBOs, how they change w.r.t. conformation and what it can tell us about conjugated systems. We find that WBOs are correlated with Hammett constants. (6/8) https://t.co/PrTRMXkUSz

When we compare the MM torsion profiles generated with the interpolated torsion force constants and MM torsion profiles generated with OpenFF version 1.3.0, we get lower RMSE when compared to QM torsion scans. (5/8) https://t.co/zV9DS17rGd
Given this relationship, we interpolated the force constants for a given set of molecules with the same torsion type using the WBOs of the central bond. (4/8) https://t.co/4U7HPuTbYr

The Wiberg Bond order (WBO) is pretty much free from an AM1BCC calculation which is used to get charges for molecules in Amber and Open force field. The WBO is also linear with torsion barrier heights of the same torsion types in different chemical environments. (3/8) https://t.co/nLVkgO7ea1

Why is this important? Here, the four protonation states of the same biphenyl have very different QM torsion profiles, however most force fields treat them all the same because the change in protonation state is outside of the local torsion type atoms. (2/8) https://t.co/ygyzMjaU8Z

Really excited to finally share our work on capturing non-local through-bond effects in torsion parameters using fractional bond orders@JessMaat @dga_smith @dotsdl @davidlmobley @jchodera https://t.co/YOLtcSTZJN (1/8)

Meyer et al. (2017, eLife) sequenced four mitogenomes and two partial nuclear genomes of the extinct straight-tusked elephant and showed that it was closely related to the African forest elephant.https://t.co/EJ58tHPUnH

Two ancient DNA papers are cited in the new IUCN Red List assessment (Gobush et al.2021), which finally treats African elephants as two separate species.These papers showed that, indeed, savanna and forest elephants are two diverged lineages isolated for a long time.

In practice, you solve interpersonal problems by treating them as real and addressing them directly (talking to the person, forgiving them, etc). That seems better than 'it's illusory, so let go'. What am I missing?

The implication seems to be "you're both watching illusory movies on illusory screens, and if you meditate and realize this then the problem will melt away, like any other illusory phenomenon". Hence advice like 'let go', 'process your emotions internally', etc.

One thing that confuses me about Buddhism: if all phenomena are illusory ("empty"), and interpersonal problems are phenomena - and therefore illusory - then what are you supposed to do about difficult interpersonal problems?

Anyway, definitely read this review - and some of the references therein - if you are interested.
I interpreted (perhaps misinterpreted) her optimism about the potential contribution of genetics to social and educational research in this context - it seemed to me to be what she was getting at.

MR has plenty of its own pitfalls and assumptions, but it has already provided useful insights into non-genetic factors affecting epidemiological traits, which are not obviously less complex than those discussed by Harden.

However that doesn't mean genetic data have no potential role to play. For example I was very surprised the book made no mention of Mendelian Randomization, an approach which uses genetic associations to explore how non-genetic factors causally affect each other

I agree current PGS are not in themselves very useful for these questions, and the book overstates their interpretability. Indeed I expect there will rarely be much inherent merit in finding which bits of DNA are associated with certain social traits in certain settings.

One aspect in which I perhaps depart from Graham and Molly, and from some other critical reviewers, is on genetics' potential role in understanding social and cognitive traits, and Harden's presentation thereof.
The latter in particular was something I reluctantly excluded from my own short review, as I found it the weakest element of the book.
But I agree with the criticism about the elision of different GWAS settings, and how the book tries to have it both ways in its treatment of differences between and within ancestral groups.

I still think the book makes a very valuable contribution and starting point for wider discussion of these issues, not least because it's much better than several notable previous books in this space. A low bar perhaps.

The truth is, words fitting the SA**E pattern are pretty rare, and either have repeated letters, or rare letters in the * positions. But I guess this choice, on average in the very long run, might match slightly more positions for S, A, and E, but in the short term probably not.

In the second one (above) the S at the first position is stronger than the A and E, because S has a much lower overall frequency, with acts as the background frequency. But does this help with Wordle?

The version above actually uses equiprobable letters as the background frequencies when calculating relative entropy (information content in bits). However, for English, this isn't great because letters have very different frequencies. Here is a version that uses empirical counts https://t.co/dFkr5dzv3J

We know that a web page is not enough to capture just how much Debbie will be missed, but we wanted to capture memories that reflect how much she touched our lives at @genome_gov. https://t.co/c2WgDUErBV

"We have at least a thousand documents which in some way illustrate her influence, capture her voice and detail her expertise across multiple domains of genome science and technology." - @genome_gov‚Äôs historian Chris Donohue

Our amazing history team put together a web page of quotes and archival documents that document Debbie‚Äôs large impact at @genome_gov. They were shocked at just how many times her name came up in our archive.

She served on the advisory group for the Center for Research on Genomics and Global Health and was a champion of diversity in genomics since the days of HapMap. I will miss her very much.‚Äù‚ÄØ Charles Rotimi, @genome_gov‚Äôs Scientific Director
‚ÄúI am saddened‚ÄØ beyond words. Debbie (a beautiful and kind human being) was a friend and a great supporter of me."

Debbie was an advisor on the International Haplotype (HapMap) Project. She was an advocate for diversity in research from the start, and she was one of the first researchers to understand the importance of genetic variation.

"She was a role model of how to be an advocate for women in science, and or promoting opportunities for trainees and‚ÄØearly-stage‚ÄØinvestigators. She will be greatly missed!‚Äù - Carolyn Hutter, our Director of Division of Genome Sciences
‚ÄúShe could‚ÄØbe frank while simultaneously being a supportive mentor and cheerleader for what we were trying to accomplish at NHGRI."

The applicant replied, ‚ÄúNo we are not, and I will tell you why.‚Äù The two of them locked horns engaged in a fierce but healthy debate. Debbie was a very powerful woman that you just had to respect.‚Äù - Rudy Pozzatti, our Deputy Director in the Division of Extramural Operations

"One of my fondest memories of her was from an applicant interview many years ago. After the applicant finished their presentation Debbie had high praise, but the last thing she said was, 'Your application has one flaw: your research team is too insular.'‚Äù
‚ÄúDebbie was no nonsense, but very respectful of the peer review process."
She leveraged her significant impact and her standing in the field of genomics to champion for women in science.

When the Human Genome Project (HGP) began in the early 1990s, Debbie was often one of the only women in the room during planning meetings. Regardless she never shied away from being an active,engaged, and critical participant.

Some of the many things Debbie was known for was her frankness, mentorship to others, her dedication to studying genetic variation and her contribution to countless important, historic science projects.
‚ÄúI will remember how she dragged half her lab to my dissertation defense to cheer me on.‚Äù - Lucia Hindorff, Program Director in our Division of Genomic Medicine

‚ÄúI benefited from her mentorship in the mid-2000s when she joined my dissertation committee and taught me everything there was to know about linkage disequilibrium and association studies. She knew how to ask hard questions and what each of her students needed to thrive."

Debbie was an educator, advocate and mentor for many @genome_gov staff throughout the years. She believed that genetics and genomics education was a crucial part of training future generations of clinicians and researchers.
Although Debbie Nickerson was never actually employed at @genome_gov, judging from how beloved she was and her impact at NHGRI, you would think that she was.

Along with the entire genomics community, we were saddened to learn of Dr. Debbie Nickerson's passing last month. She made an enormous impact on science and on many people's hearts. https://t.co/c2WgDUErBV https://t.co/fbuXw07PsP

So for those of you who are thinking about a career in academia or currently applying to PhD programs - many of us love being in academia. I wanted you see this opinion. Some of us have tried other careers, and still we choose academia. 4/4 #AcademicChatter #phdchat

Working in academia is hard work. The most rewarding careers in life usually are; that's why it's called work. My purpose is to make a difference, changing people's lives in a positive way.  Being a professor in academia gives me the opportunity to strive for this every day. 3/4

2) I am able to be creative and innovative and ask interesting questions in my research. My lab gets to decide what we work on. Research freedom is priceless. 3) I feel like I am making an impact on the world through research, service, and teaching. 4) I get paid to learn. 2/4

I love my job. Lately, I have seen so much negativity about working in academia. I know this career path may not be for everyone. But I love it. I feel compelled to share why? 1) I am able to teach and mentor the next generation of scientists. 1/4 #AcademicChatter #phdchat

But 25 & 50 lb bags of materials, like dry clay, plaster, & glaze making materials is different. Wagon to house, but slumps on dolly & have to carry down steps. So need plastic sled I can drill holes in & put rope through to control descent. Then drag to storage. Hope it works.

It‚Äôs a good thing rolling 25 lb bags & 50 lb boxes of clay down the steps is actually good for the clay, I call it extreme wedging & it keeps it soft. I even use the technique to rehab old stiff clay & it works beautifully

Since I‚Äôm not supposed to lift more than 5 lb, this is how I get 50 lb boxes of clay from the driveway to my basement: sturdy garden wagon to door, little dolly up the stairs to the basement steps, let box slide/tumble down steps, dolly to storage area

At least the stuff I bought from the 2nd pottery supplier is all dry stuff, so I think it should be alright in the cold so I can wait until tomorrow to unload it, b/c I have to buy a sled to get most of the 25 & 50 lb bags down the stairs to the basement
I always think it‚Äôs a little rude when there are two full service pottery suppliers to go to them, since they load up your car for you, w/ a couple hundred $ worth of stuff from the other place.

Seriously, it is going to be under 0* for the next 2-3 weeks, & I can manage that mostly, it is the fact that I have to make many trips to my car this morning at -9* to unload all the clay I bought, & then go to the competing pottery & have them load up my car w/lots of stuff

If nothing else, I hope this period shakes many academics free from the current Stockholm Syndrome I see everywhere: sluggish, bloated, risk-averse institutions and terrible funding systems are *not* an inevitable part of academia. Change is possible.

After decades of complacency with the traditional funding model, it feels like COVID has spurred an explosion of new models. Yes, some models won't work. But we'll emerge from this period with a much better sense of which ones do.

Some notable recent examples: Fast Grants to speed up the distribution of funding in areas of urgent need; Focused Research Organisations to create nimble, time-limited orgs with a clear focus; new institutes with strong core funding to free up grant-writing time.
For those who haven't been following, there is a *ton* of money going into experimentation in the funding and organisation of science - see this handy catalogue, for instance: https://t.co/u4KAL4LdKn

This is definitely a valid concern, but given the standard academic funding and organisation models are transparently broken it's hard not to be pretty excited about the current pace of innovation in the research philanthropy space. https://t.co/TglZyopydE

I usually say:different career stages have different selective pressures.It applies here too: a PhD from 2000 (or before) has had different selective pressures than a PhD in 2022.

Now that we have robots for extractions, customized illumina kits and companies to do things for us; while saying " I have >1000 samples and my advisor did their PhD with 20 samples "IMO the challenges were there but we're different.

20-30 years ago it was not possible to get Google maps on the field. 10-15 years ago researchers spent months on the lab optimizing extractions and getting microsatellites. This was extremely punishing and frustrating. It's easy for some of us to dismiss these hardships ...

I disagree with this.First, I have to admit I've been finding it increasingly hard to navigate as an early career researcher. We're always stressed, struggling to keep up with increasingly demanding deadlines and goals.However, older researchers had different issues ... https://t.co/Wx7ch64mCd

5/6 These findings along with the original outbreak investigations strongly support the use of pneumococcal vaccines in all shipyard workers to prevent further vaccine preventable outbreaks in shipyards.
4/6 Evidence of transmission between shipyards (that have an internationally mobile workforce) also contributed to the outbreaks but to a lesser extent.

3/6 ST801 is rare outside of these outbreaks and may well be adapted to colonise the harsh lung conditions shipyard workers are exposed to. However, wider community transmission of ST801 in adults in Europe could not be ruled out with this data.
2/6 Huge diversity within serotype 4 ST801 contributing to the outbreaks suggests harsh shipyard conditions were driving multiple independent invasive disease cases.

{hits send tentatively, wondering whether this does actually make sense}

(And yes, I think those who get this, get this, and to those who don‚Äôt it will sound ridiculous. And of course it‚Äôs bass ackwards - everyone‚Äôs strengths should be acknowledged as the default, regardless of who they are!)

I‚Äôm not through thinking about this at all - all I‚Äôm saying is that, given where we are with people‚Äôs real understanding of autism, there are risks and disadvantages to disclosing- but there may also be some upsides, & as I love using my brain, that specific upside makes me happy

There are things I‚Äôm just good at and I can do very fast, intuitively. Previously, this upset people sometimes as it didn‚Äôt fit the box they had me in. It‚Äôs like now it‚Äôs ‚Äúallowed‚Äù, because ‚Äúwell, she‚Äôs autistic..‚Äù?

It‚Äôs not always easy to be openly #ActuallyAutistic (thanks massive stigma and ableism). But - besides the incredible relief of not always having to sustain a mask (saving so much energy!) - the thing I‚Äôm finding is that I am actually *more free* to use my strengths!

Millenia of persecution has understandably created a lot of anxiety about making Jewish spaces feel safe. But we must ask ourselves -- what are we protecting ourselves from? What message do we send when we use vehicles of white supremacy (police) to guard these spaces?

Lastly, here is a thread Rabbi Danya Ruttenberg (who is not Black) wrote yesterday. She notes how policing Jewish spaces not only makes Jews of color unwelcome--it also would not have kept the gunman from entering in the first place.https://t.co/pk7w6i6Miv

Take note of the quote pulled from the comments on his Facebook post ‚ÄúNo one had any idea he was Jewish. They just saw some black guy with a Torah and panicked. Given the fact that ALL crimes in Crown Heights against Jews are done by POC, can you blame the Jews for panicking...?"

This article reports on an incident where Yehuda Webster was cornered by 20-30 Hasidic Jews in Crown Heights for carrying a Torah while Black.‚ÄúThey didn‚Äôt say, ‚ÄòWhere is the tallit?‚Äô They said, ‚ÄòWhy do you have a Torah?‚Äô‚Äùhttps://t.co/xXGiB8s7AL

Nylah Burton expressed a similar sentiment at the same time.‚ÄúWhite congregants may not be police officers, but they often carry the same bias towards people of color and black people. With guns, their bias could still get someone killed.‚Äùhttps://t.co/LjzYGXftsi
‚ÄúWhen these distrusting white Jews can turn to a person with a gun and tell them that I don‚Äôt belong, that becomes a threat to my personal safety in the scariest way.‚Äù

In the wake of the Tree of Life massacre, Bentley Addison wrote about experiences where being Black made him feel excluded from Jewish spaces, and how a police presence would make it worse.https://t.co/5Qw9aIGyjL
‚ÄúThe same police forces that many Jewish communities would call in for protection are state enforcers of the white space that do not represent safety for Jews of color.‚Äù
In this piece, Rebecca Pierce discusses how the assumption that Jews are white by default excludes and harms Jews of color from Jewish spaces.https://t.co/uuZzJLOSue

Let's start with a two-tweet poem that Ma Nishtana wrote yesterday. This was in response to Saturday's hostage situation but reflects the broader experience of being Black in Jewish spaces.https://t.co/kiz8oTNdjb

A friend asked me for some literature on how the presence of police in Jewish spaces makes Jews of Color feel unwelcome.If he's asking, others are asking too. So here's a few pieces I've read over the years--all of which are by Black Jews and their experiences in Jewish spaces. https://t.co/CPJ9gsPZ2G

These mutations will be lost by purifying selection, and  this process determines the time-dependency in the early stage of pandemics. Its effects can be ameliorated by considering the timescale and focussing on internal branches of the tree. 8/n
Any evolutionary analysis that relies upon information largely from the tips of a pandemic evolutionary tree i likely to include a lot of noise and give unreliable estimates. 7/n
We show that the tips contain many ‚Äòtransient deleterious mutations‚Äô, sequence changes that are harmful to the virus but that will not persist over time. 6/n

The inferred rates of evolution of SARC-CoV-2 dropped by 50% within a year and H1N1 by 100%. Crucially, we show that rates of evolution on the tips, or leaves, of a phylogenetic tree, are 2-4 times higher than internal branches. 5/n
We studied this penomenon for the first year of two different viral pandemics, a coronaviral and influenza one. 4/n
Knowing the rate of evolution matters for inferring timescales of events from viral sequence data. Choosing the wrong rate can heavily bias inferred timescales of events. 3/n
The rates of evolution of viruses vary with the timescale of measurement, a kind of ‚Äòevolutionary relativity‚Äô, where rates appear slower the longer the timescale over which they are measured. 2/n

The higher-level takeaway is that we should be cautious when using sketching and take the time to understand its bias and how it affects downstream analyses. 5/5

Sometimes the bias is extreme, sometimes not. For example, there are cases when the true Jaccard is 90%, but the expected value of the estimator is only 44%. Depending on your use-case, you may or may not find this bias tolerable. 4/5

But, as we show, estimating the Jaccard from the minimizer sketch (which is NOT the minhash sketch) turns out to be biased, for all window sizes, even with growing sequence length. We show this theoretically and empirically. 3/5
A good estimator should be unbiased, i.e. its expected value should be the true value. MinHash Jaccard is a great example --- it will on average give you the true Jaccard. 2/5

In our new paper, we show that using a minimizer sketch to estimate the k-mer Jaccard similarity between two sequences is potentially problematic. This is joint work with Antonio Blanca, @RSHarrisPSU  @DavidKoslicki, and Mahdi Belbasi. https://t.co/f1AGlf7rto 1/5

Orchestration of the entire analysis process is especially  exciting as this is where it's possible to really accelerate biomedical computing. I'm very excited for the next phase of @useAnVIL ! 11/11 End üßµ

As analyses move to the cloud, data commons such as @useAnVIL can serve multiple purposes: (1) access to NIH datasets without fees; (2) access to analysis environments, tools, and applications without costly setup; and (3) orchestration of management of data and tools. 10/n
Looking forward, I see cloud use growing substantially as universities/institutions refresh and augment their existing HPC and realize there are key areas where the cloud can save $. 9/

There's definitely effort required to use cloud services well. Fortunately, cloud-based data commons like @useAnVIL enable the use of these services transparently and often without needing to know technical details. 8/

Let's turn to the effort to move analyses to the cloud. The cloud requires a new way of working where the large variety of services are used to meet each need of an analysis. This is different than most HPC systems where you get a scheduler and file system quota. 7/

Knowing the cloud may be cheaper, the next key question is how expensive will an analysis be on the cloud? There is much active work across the NIH cloud commons and within @useAnVIL to provide better cost estimates and cost controls for analyses. Stay tuned! 6/

Each of these steps is complex and can require significant amounts of time/effort to do well. Data egress fees can be especially large when working with large primary datasets such as omics and imaging. 5/

However, there are several reasons that the cloud may be less costly in the long run: (1) application/environment management; (2) data and metadata management; (3) use of only data/compute resources needed; and (4) no data egress fees. 4/

Cost: absolutely a concern, especially for institutions that have made their own investment in HPC, which is most research-focused institutions. However, there are costs for maintaining and growing institutional HPC, as well as a full refresh of the HPC down the line. 3/
There are often two main concerns about cloud-based data commons: (1) cost and (2) effort to move analyses to the cloud. Let's discuss both 2/

A scalable tool for fat distribution may allow:identification of individuals ‚Äòflying under the radar‚Äô with undiagnosed lipodystrophyenhance clinical risk assessmentmeasure response to a lifestyle/medication intervention

@maulik and co. previously noted that the Amazon Halo device estimate TOTAL fat percentage using just smartphone images- https://t.co/qHebXV9z46Our results ‚Äî if prospectively validated ‚Äî suggest potential to do considerably betterAllowing for nuanced distribution assessment

Estimation of fat distribution ‚Äî despite strong scientific support ‚Äî has not entered routine clinical practice due to requirement of clinical imagingUse of simple imaging modalities such as silhouette images may enable scalable approaches to population health
These results suggest that ‚Äî for any given BMI and waist circumferenceThere is a significant gradient in risk according to VAT/ASAT ratio https://t.co/IBQ67H9x1p

Turning to clinical relevance of this silhouette-image derived measure of central adiposity (‚ÄòVAT/ASAT‚Äô)We demonstrate strong associations with prevalence of diabetes and coronary artery diseaseLargely independent of simple measures such as BMI or weight circumference https://t.co/tk8VNMmErk

One way to index risk from central adiposity is to simply divide ‚Äòvisceral‚Äô by ‚Äòsubcutaneous‚Äô adipose tissue volumesThis measure (VAT/ASAT) is considerably harder to predictBut again machine learning models trained on silhouette substantially outperformed other strategies https://t.co/j11IjhpGLw

Recent consensus doc suggest waist circumference ‚Äî a surrogate of central fat ‚Äî as a ‚Äòvital sign‚Äôbut measuring waist with a tape measure doesn‚Äôt distinguish fat under the skin (neutral) vs fat around organs (visceral)see two participants with same waist circumferences: https://t.co/UUbPdflr3y

These machine learning models performed considerably better than predictors that used only variables such as age, sex, and waist circumference ‚Äî as well as previously developed models that included additional clinical variables or ‚Äòimpedance‚Äô ‚Äî a scale measurement of total fat https://t.co/p7xtlP8iB6

We downloaded raw MRI images from >40,000 UK Biobank And converted each participant‚Äôs images into just two silhouette images ‚Äî one from the front, one from the sideUsing a machine learning CNN model, these simple images could accurately estimate fat depot volumes https://t.co/ETI39MCqWG

New from @MarcusKlarqvist + @saaket_agrawal!Beyond overall adiposity, DISTRIBUTION of fat is a key driver of cardiometabolic healthMost prior studies used medical imaging (DEXA, MRI, CT) to quantifyCan we accurately estimate distribution with just a person‚Äôs silhouette? https://t.co/OhMH0B3EA4

Very few of these things are "trade offs" to (say) economics + certainly one wants to have all these tools sharpened up, improved, prepared and better to be deployed either for managing the next SARS-CoV-2 variant (definitely on risk registers) or next virus/bacteria/AMR outbreak

Publics in general follow advice, guidelines and are sensible; vaccination drives need to engage with vaccine hesitant groups early with broad community support; models are informative, and are best integrated into a holistic view of at least healthcare (ideally economy).

Wastewater is a good source of at least some virus transmission (no doubt way more AMR etc); genomic sequencing, ideally randomly sampled, can provide near real time views of pathogen evolution; real time data sharing provides confidence in stats and broad response.

View from here; mRNA vaccines are safe and work; robust large clinical trials can be executed at scale; masks cut down respiratory transmission; Respiratory viruses don't like dry fresh circulating air; mass contact tracing is feasible and reduces transmission; mass testing works

We ... need to get into a more stable phase of this pandemic first (worldwide for sure; it is going to be a long journey), but we are allowed to *learn from* the last two years *plus* the variation of good or not so good responses worldwide - and this is valid beyond COVID.

despite all the analysis and complaining about how extortionate it is it continues. It continues despite there being so many other lower cost and better (fewer retractions, etc) models available from lots of other fields. It is not like publishing in math has an entirely

it out since the benefits in terms of visibility, future grants, legacy etc make it clearly well worth it. The academic publishing system is amazingly well constructed (at least in biomedical and related fields, since I did not see this kind of behavior in Physics etc). because

of the revenue to the established ones (in various ways) to incentivise them to not cooperate. And additionally, the APCs, while appearing large in isolation, are a tiny fraction of a typical biomedical grant, so while there's a fair amount of complaining, by and large PIs shell

they potentially never make it to the high reputation and funds side if the other side defect and only pull people over if they publish in the prison. The established ones have low incentive to cooperate so the payoff matrix is asymmetrical here. Also, the prison kicks back some

Maybe one can think of it as a prisoner's dilemma. There are two groups of academics, upstarts with low reputation and funds, and established with high reputation and funds. If you are interested in our approach see @HyeEirik presenting part of the approach and results here https://t.co/mex2TnUeTTduring our smallRNA bioinformatics club series (https://t.co/fuSOor7kJy)
This study started back in 2014 and actually made us realize, back in 2015, that the human microRNA complement needed reannotation. which ultimately led to the creation of @MirGeneDB

This work was heavily inspired by previous work from @Marc_Halushka @Mendell_lab @KennethWWitwer  using the tools of the @FriedlanderLab and others, not on Twitter.Thank you for comments and help with data acquisition @MichaelHackenbe
Finally, we show a set of clearly deregulated microRNAs in metastases with strong potential as biomarkers and for future mechanistic studies. https://t.co/34DBEnE8l1 https://t.co/LcxuvNvCxZ
We also show that cell-type specific microRNAs inform about cellular heterogeneity in tissues, rather than deregulation https://t.co/F4voX20h72 https://t.co/FXS3dajRvV
metastatic sites, while sharing some deregulated miRNAs, differ in microRNA expression https://t.co/VtfX3AVoLN https://t.co/P6fw1NkspL
We find that microRNA expression of correctly performed experiments is independent of study and resemble location in the body (i.e. organ) https://t.co/Z7QCq4p7wQ https://t.co/W5s9zfMn9e

We establish a stringent, reproducible and easily expandable bioinformatics pipeline (https://t.co/u9DYAtl9ez) that we applied on all previously published (depending on availability) and a large range of novel smallRNA sequencing datasets, altogether 268 datasets.

Among them are- lack of correction for background expression- different metastatic sites were not analyzed as separate entities- expression cut-off level for microRNAs to ensure biological relevance are typically not used

Very happy to see our microRNA metastases paper out. co-led by @HyeEirik and by many fantastic colleaguesWe show the reasons for previously published contradicting reports of de-regulated #microRNAs in colorectal cancer #tumors and #metastases: https://t.co/cBGQQWos1Y

The focal mutation cannot know its fitness consequences if it were to co-occur with this de novo compensatory mutation. It cannot see whether its fate is death or reproduction when it occurs.

We could imagine elaborate scenarios where a modifier system learns, through natural selection, to detect when this compensatory mutation co-occurs. But we could play the same thought experiment with a novel de novo compensatory mutation that occurs alongside the new mutation.
However, whether the mutation occurs or not is causally independent of this compensatory mutation co-occurring and restoring fitness.

As a thought experiment, consider a mutation in a region that is intolerant of any mutations unless there's also a compensatory mutation that restores fitness. Selection has lead to all sorts of beautiful mechanisms to repair DNA damage and prevent mutations in this region.

This latter process is very cool biologically, and it speaks to the long reach of selection. It has been shown before in other systems, but establishing it in a new system is nice work. But it does not refute the first tweet.

However, because modifier systems could alter mutation rates along the genome in a non-uniform way (e.g. leading to covariance between genes density and mutation rates), you can end up with a statistical dependence between mutation rates and their potential fitness outcomes.

A mutation cannot "see" its fitness effect¬†‚Äî¬†this is a central tenant of evolution that has not been refuted. This is saying there is causal independence between a mutation and its fitness effect.

This has been observed in other polyploids and interpreted as evidence for hybridization, with one parental genome ‚Äútaking over‚Äù the other one. But in fish, this does not line up... so clearly evolution after whole genome duplication is more complex than this.
Second, we show that duplicated chromosomes have evolved asymmetrically after the tetraploidization: one chromosome copy often retained more genes and/or had lower evolutionary rates.

It also suggests that the ancestral teleost was likely an autoploid, resulting from genome doubling within a species, as its duplicated chromosomes were so similar that they could pair during meiosis.
This means that on those chromosomes, genes don‚Äôt really have orthology and paralogy relationships between fish clades.

This has profound implications for comparative genomics in fish. In particular, several duplicated chromosomes were still exchanging alleles during meiosis at the time when major fish clades diverged.

We are indeed missing names in our contributors file. We are missing contributions of names we have already listed.There is a lot to fill in .. but we now have a place to do it and show it to the world.We will continue working on this & welcome all input!

Thanks to the communication between anvi'o codebase and this web page, an individual's contributions to anvi'o, whether it is a program, opinion, workflow, or a tutorial, can be brought together in a single page that can go into a CV.Here is an example: https://t.co/GxdR2t0zcV

And most critically, this web page recognizes the members of the anvi'o community much better and offers a framework to give people credit for their notable contributions that help the anvi'o community beyond coding: https://t.co/gm8WxlfcO6

We at https://t.co/2cZHQ2ri5w worked very hard to turn anvi'o into a community project, but having anvi'o under our domain  perhaps made it difficult for others to feel ownership of the platform.The new web page also separates anvi'o from us & gives anvi'o its independence.
Second, it houses a new community blog (at https://t.co/oxu0t7uDH4) that is open for anyone who needs a revenue to get out their tutorials or opinions that may be relevant to the anvi'o community.

This new web page achieves multiple things. First, it offers an environment to bring together all help for anvi'o programs and artifacts as well as theoretical and hands-on tutorials in a single place, so new and existing anvi'o users can steer through these comfortably.

We compared our method to other open source shape descriptors using a series of PDE5 inhibitors of expected shape similarity, and investigated how different molecular conformers are handled. RGMolSA shows promising capability in both tests. https://t.co/rZ36ScuUeE
These descriptors are fast to calculate and don't rely on prior alignment of molecules or generation of meshes.

Here we present the mathematics underpinning a new approach for molecular shape approximation. RGMolSA uses the 9-element Riemannian metric to describe the surface geometry. We obtain this by considering the spectrum of the Laplacian associated with the surface.

Shape similarity between molecules is a useful tool for predicting structurally diverse hits in Ligand-Based Virtual Screening. There is currently no absolute definition for the shape of a molecule, instead we rely on mathematical approximation to generate descriptors.

Thought experiment. If an academic job has 200 applicants, the committee ranks everyone by application. How far down the list would you have to go before you'd get to candidates that are significantly worse at the job as a whole?
For my job, there was 200+ applicants and I am under no illusions that there were not many on that list that could have done as good a job as I, or better. 3/

The academic job is so multi-facetted and hiring is challenging/biased, so I wonder whether the 'true best' candidate is most likely to get hired, or whether there is much difference between good candidates. 2/

There's been some talk about how academia is losing it's shine and that we could be losing the best scientists to industry. I think we should be supporting ECR but I question whether we were ever getting the best candidates. 1/

CHD's can be caused by chromosomal differences, some deletion/duplication syndromes, single gene differences or even environmental factors. https://t.co/vFOcgrtWA8

A congenital heart difference may be diagnosed prenatally, in the newborn phase, or later in life. This is really dependent on the severity of the condition and the signs & symptoms the individual has.

A congenital heart difference is one of the most common type of birth difference an individual may have. 1 in 100 newborns will be born with a CHDEnjoy our infographics or checkout our colleagues at @BostonChildrens webpage: https://t.co/DRVMd39EIS https://t.co/8Brg8CUf9x

Our findings support a model where #meconium is sterile at birth and is colonised in the hours/days after birth, with rate of colonisation varying across infants.5/
#meconium bacterial load (BL) varied significantly across infants and was correlated with time of sample collection. Samples with low BL had higher human #mitochondrial DNA content. 4/

So, we‚Äôve discovered that this antitfungal symbiont is also moonlighting as a nutritional one. Read more here! (FIN)  https://t.co/8GV9Pwzpy9

Finally, @AudParish tests in bees under nutrient stress grow better with B.apis and it turns out they do! If you give bees a diet reduced by 25% nutrition, they grow to be small, sad bees. But add B.apis, and now they are the same size as their full nutrition counterparts! (7/N)
It turns out, if you look at the evolutionary history of this group, B.apis has acquired 3 different amino acid transporters in its trajectory - pretty neat! (6/N)

Next, @AudParish used a combination of basic microbiology, metabolomics and comparative genomics, & found that B.apis can make all essential amino acids, can grow without any of them in defined media, and secretes one important one - lysine - into the larval diet! (5/N)
Turns out, of the microbes we find associated with baby bees, only B. apis can survive in RJ. Super cool and means B.apis is truly adapted to live with honey bees. (4/N)

It seems, therefore, a microbe associated with niches in the colony that have royal jelly. Royal Jelly, for those unfamiliar, is an extremely antimicrobial substance - it‚Äôs complex, and nutrient rich, but full of antimicrobial peptides and highly acidic. (3/N)

Our protagonist, Bombella apis, is an acetic acid symbiont of honey bees that is often found associated with brood, nectar, and queen digestive tracts. Based on 16S rRNA gene amplicons we know that this microbe isn‚Äôt found in worker digestive tracts - at least not very much (2/N)
So excited to share with y‚Äôall the next chapter in our work on Bombella apis, led by the amazingly talented @AudParish. (1/N) https://t.co/8GV9Pwzpy9

Overall, I think the view that science is somehow at odds with art, or poetry, etc. is narrow. Art can provide depth and context to an otherwise technical paper or subject in a way science alone cannot.

The genetics in this paper (https://t.co/lE1V4oxHmo) are fascinating: recessive alleles that form compound heterozygotes leading to subtle phenotypes. Yet if I were to teach this paper again, I'd feature and discuss "Christina's World" alongside it.

"The CMT community has embraced Olson as an icon," from this lovely reflection in Wyeth's painting and its importance from someone with CMT (https://t.co/WSMKY0cnmh). When I TA'd genetics, we read and taught a paper using WGS to find clinically relevant leading to CMT.

Olson's condition, while undiagnosed, has been speculated and discussed in the medical literature. Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease seems to be likely (https://t.co/As2MGh4Rqf, see also links therein).

The subject of this painting is Christina Olson, Wyeth's neighbor and friend. Olson developed a degenerative muscle condition and preferred crawling ‚Äîas depicted‚Äî rather than a wheelchair. The MOMA has a great video exploring this piece and disability: https://t.co/uZTGDnOGTs

I've been thinking about Andrew Wyeth's 1948 painting "Christina's World" and how art can enrich how we teach genetics. At first glance, it features a woman sitting in a pleasant field. Yet look closer, and you notice tension in her arms and hands. https://t.co/1Qy1lhFmMG

In Omicron one has these plus prior infection plus vaccination x age. It is I think going to be a different experience in different places, even in the UK, let alone between countries.

This means I think the Omicron wave is going to have quite hetreogenous trajectories in terms of both hospitalisations and deaths in different countries - unlike the first wave, Alpha etc where one mainly had age and contact (NPIs) driving differences.

For vaccination, as I keep on banging on about, it is vaccination stratified by age which is the most important thing. The aggregate numbers ... have meaning... but it is really vaccination numbers >60.

London also has a lot of healthcare provision in a reasonably close geographic region - easy for ambulances to be diverted to share healthcare loads. So healthcare stress is easier to spread in London.

For London vs UK was the epicentre of UK's very first wave, where we don't really know how many people were infected (though one can do some "backcasting") and then the diverse cultures in London has lead to more hetreogenous vaccination.
Really we need immunity levels due to vaccination (pretty well tracked) and prior infection (likely important to prevent hospitalisation as well as reducing transmission).
It's tempting to assume that London will be a good model for the rest of the UK, or other places across Europe, but one needs lots of caution here.

That tissue can be severed by compression all around the trunk. There's no room for it to grow outwards and the preexisting tissue converts from phloem into xylem. Without phloem to carry food down to the roots, the roots will eventually starve and the whole tree will die.

Anyway, I hope the toolkit continues to be useful. You can access all the training materials here: https://t.co/00oO9wzP7A

It was a fun, challenging departure from my normal bioinformatics duties and an excuse to work with amazing old and new collaborators. Thanks to @CDC_AMD for the opportunity and support; I'm proud of this small contribution.

Our target audience was epis at state/local public health depts but we hoped the information would resonate with others responding to the pandemic. It's been humbling to hear how our modules have even been used for training in other countries.  üåç

The recorded short presentations get the most attention (and definitely took the most effort to prepare under our clearance requirements) but each module also includes links to carefully selected manuscripts and resources for more detailed learning.

The toolkit has since grown to 18 modules, presented by 12 public health experts from across federal, state, and city government as well as universities. We've tried to offer a balanced mix of background concepts, case studies, and technical resources.

Although development started in Oct-2020, the page finally went live on Jan-8-2021 with the first 7 training modules, just as domestic genomic surveillance of SARS-CoV-2 was starting to accelerate. (remember B.1.1.7?)

Please feel free to add any other suggestions that you might have. (10/n)
8) If none of these option solve the issue, contacting the authors might help. (9/n)
7) Some sequences are included in NCBI/ENA/DDBJ without a reference in the publication. Searches in the database with species name, gene function, or gene name can help. (8/n)
6) Sequences can be extracted from alignment figures by typing every single letter. If you are lucky, a BLAST search with the first 20+ characters already gives you the full sequence. (7/n)
5) BLASTn can also work with sequence fragments that you find in plasmid maps or antisense constructs (after reverting the sequence). (6/n)

4) If no ID and no full sequence is available, primer sequences can help you. They might be included in results, methods, or supplements. A BLASTn with forward and reverse primer sequence at the NCBI against the relevant species can lead to the full sequence. (5/n)

A lot will fail, but the few that work will be impressive achievements just becuase so much of the ecosystem would have had to mature (in terms of providing better UX) to reach meaningful mass adoption (at least to the extent it's hyped up to atm.)

The hard thing about seeing crypto from this perspective is that it takes some of the excitement away... I mean you literally face every hard thing about building a successful web(2) product, in an entirely novel ecosystem, with social dynamics we haven't yet fully figured out.
The work will be done when the only difference you notice is a 'powered by [some blockchain]' label somewhere.
and, there are lots of creators building meaningful things with all this in mind. Give it a few more years, I think we'll see crypto being applied to things in ways you'll never (need to) hear about.

To be clear I think it's the ways people play into the hype that make it sound like everything needs a tokenized economy. There's a lot of brand appeal (and some hate) that comes with web3. I personally don't mind the fresh enthusiasm for the web that it brought in...

I personally don't think it matters all that much. Blockchains will be abstracted to the point that the web3 component would simply be an integration within an otherwise standard web(2) product or application...

But the second you really delve beyond those primary use-cases and the labels fall off, how important is that distinction to the experience expected by an average user who just wants to get something done? (timely, fast, cheap, easy)
‚ÄìCurrency for one, NFTs as an extension of collectables, DAOs as tools for democracy and everything that supports the ecosystem...
There are many obvious wins within the larger crypto community (for people who want to do stuff with tokens) that were suddenly feasible with the advent of blockchains.

Need more conversations like this. It's really unnecessary to make a distinction between web2 and web3 to the degree some people do. Most people won't care, and it isn't realistic to expect them to.https://t.co/VUP5vG9bcP

I am therefore just starting the journey, I now have a serious genetic risk of cancer. It will be part of my life, and maybe my children‚Äôs lives. But I don‚Äôt have cancer today. I will need annual checks, with them I hope I can manage that risk. /18

So all good? Sadly not completely‚Ä¶We have no idea why I grow these polyps‚Ä¶ and genetic testing for people in my place isn‚Äôt established as it is an uncommon condition at my age. I also have to work out the risk of my two daughters inheriting problem. /17 https://t.co/zQ4clO3ihD

Literally called ‚Äòthe evil twin of polyps‚Äô, in the research paper I read. They have a 30-50% turning cancerous in 3-5 years. Had I left it, I probably wouldn‚Äôt have been seen until it was too late. I never had the symptoms after that one day in September. No other warnings.

Then, somehow the 23rd came, all 13 polyps were removed. It looks good (although the polyps are being checked in a lab). Did I over react?Not a chance, we don‚Äôt think they were cancer but‚Ä¶ the polyps I had were the sessile serrated polyps type. /14 https://t.co/fgXRbat2e4

As everyone else got excited for Christmas, I was planning logistics. It‚Äôs lonely, worried at night and worried COVID would cancel everything. I was stress, not sleeping, and wanted to ignore the whole thing.  /13

2 weeks past, nothing. I chase it but no one knows who to talk to. GP has no info. Eventually someone I phone called me back. A PA who empathiesed, they provided a number and ‚Ä¶ somehow ‚Ä¶ I was booked in within minutes. For the 23rd December. /12

You see each polyp in the colon has potential to become cancer (or hide it), and some polyps are more risk than others. So I was told I would need surgery‚Ä¶ in 6 weeks to remove and check them. The op would by confirmed in 2. /11

So I ended up, again alone, 150 miles from home to get it checked. What we found was 13 polyps. If I was 50 that 3 would be a lot. In my 30s üò¨The good news is it probably wasn‚Äôt cancer, but that isn‚Äôt the end of the story /10 https://t.co/00DpJ8bhmN

Our current "The pile of stories" state is not by necessity it is by habit.If we want to deliver on the grand promises we make in our talks, papers, grant proposals, business plans - there is only one direction to go - towards building larger and larger computational models.

In biology models/theories are replaced by stories. Stories are great for human communication. Scribbling your exciting story at the back of a napkin in a dinner with your colleagues is intellectually satisfying-come prediction time though stories are utterly useless. https://t.co/KeuhCkFJ39

This is something that I spent an inordinate amount of time - mostly during the development of BioPAX,SBGN. Compared to physics and chemistry, where mathematical models are a primary artifact of research, in biology they are often afterthoughts. https://t.co/3U9GRvrIi6
This is related to another recent twitter conversation: üëáüëáüëáWhy models/theories does not deliver in Biology? Why is Biology different from chemistry and physics? https://t.co/HFK876emOZ
Whereas a computational model, independent of how large it is, is still a falsifiable conjecture, under different assumptions, and if used correctly is still scientific knowledge.

(a) this expert integration is a case study in cognitive biases (b) produced assembled artifacts, unlike the fragments they assembled from are no longer falsifiable conjectures, therefore can not count as scientific knowledge per se.
Now we are in the money ball territory: We moved from incompatible knowledge from "irreplaceable" expert knowledge. I flat out refuse this as I witnessed so many times, in different forms that:

There is a parallel "anti assembly argument" that goes along the lines of "Some form of contextual generalization is necessary  for assembling fragments. Authors of review papers make implicit conjectures to this effect. Doing so correctly appears to be more art than science. "

Therefore "context argument" can only claim that only "some of" our findings can cross the context boundary. Others are artifacts. This is certainly true - but this weaker argument does not preclude the possibility ( and more importantly necessity) of assembly.

Yet if we didn't know this fact, and you were to demonstrate it today, you would be at the cover of a CNS journal of your choice. We would all get excited because it would have explained a lot of things in cancer and other diseases.

But if we are going to claim that our findings is only valuable inside that procedurally defined boundary, we should all close shop and do something else. If MDM2 only binds to TP53 in a single cell line, under very narrow conditions - then the scientific value of that is ~0.

We keep everything outside of that controlled boundary same procedurally (e.g. same mouse line, same growth conditions etc.) and perturb things inside the boundary (positive and negative controls). This is the source of context - it has nothing to do with biology per se.

So let's try to remove the veil - what is a "biological context"?. This goes all the way back to the times of Jacob and Monod-when we decided that one way to study biological systems is to isolate a part of it with carefully designed controls.

Also - if you think that the structure of TP53 is context independent, I have a bridge to sell. Yet, somehow a big community of scientists have no qualms obtaining structures determined in one context and using it across multiple contexts.

I beg to differ, but often get killed by both sides. Consider "MDM2 binds to TP53 and ubuquitinates it"- surely this statement has scientific value across a large set of contexts. The context argument works simply by hiding behind the lack of definition of context.

Interestingly, a similar argument is used to discard all of accumulated mol. bio. knowledge by data-driven side of systems biology: " Everything in mol. bio. is context dependent, therefore systems biology can't use it, we need to infer them from data ab initio."
This is a question that I most frequently get during my talks:"Everything in mol. bio. is context dependent, therefore it is a fool's errand to try to assemble them."

Let me be provocative: "Context" is a crutch in Molecular Biology. We throw that word around as a scapegoat to justify a lot of our methodological problems. It is intellectually lazy. A thread triggered by a recent twitter response: üëáüëáüëáhttps://t.co/LsunoFoZCA

Looks like we have a rough few weeks ahead of us before this surge burns out, with very little support or helpful guidance from our governments. Avoid fatalism: with basic steps you can greatly reduce your risk, and IMO it's worth it. Good luck.

Most important thing: read enough to calibrate your internal risk properly. My sense of the uncertainty around long COVID is enough for me to be *very* keen to avoid my kids getting infected before vaccination. Others will differ. But make your decisions informed.

Grab a bunch of RATs as soon as the current supply crunch recedes. The need for these is not going away any time soon, and they're useful for reducing the risk of social gathering (especially in between big waves).

Note that while these respirators are nominally single-use, in practice they are effective for ages - you can follow the CDC guidelines for reuse (rotate through multiple "active" masks, storing the ones you're not using in a paper bag): https://t.co/clBDXkz3KS

COVID spreads primarily as aerosol, so your focus is to avoid sharing air with others:- if you're going to socialise, do it outside if at all possible- switch your cloth/surgical masks for P2, N95, or KF94 respirators when sharing indoor air with anyone outside your household

Assume everyone else is infected. Sydney is now at ~10% prevalence (adjusting for undertesting), so any group of 6 people has a ~50% chance of 1 or more being infectious.This soaring prevalence means that negative RAT tests are much less useful - don't assume they're correct.

Even if you believe omicron disease is mild, and inevitable (both untrue IMO), it's still worth your while taking basic steps to avoid getting infected *right now*, while hospitals are overwhelmed. These don't mean shutting down your life.

The first-in-human, multi-center, open-label clinical trial will determine the safety and tolerability of 23ME-00610 in people with locally advanced or metastatic solid malignancies that have progressed after standard therapy (6/8)

23ME-00610 is a high-affinity humanized monoclonal antibody designed to bind the CD200R1 receptor & prevent the interaction of CD200 and CD200R1Preclinical data suggest this may reinvigorate tumor-exhausted T-cells and myeloid cells to restore ability to kill cancer cells (5/8)

CD200R1 is an inhibitory receptor expressed on T cells and myeloid cellsCD200, the ligand for CD200R1, is highly expressed on certain tumorsBinding of tumor associated CD200 to CD200R1 leads to immune suppression and decreased immune cell killing of cancer cells (4/8)

Using this machine learning approach along w/ our database of genetically linked health traits, 23andMe scientists discovered 3 parts of the CD200R1 pathway have an I/O genetic signature:CD200R1 receptorCD200 ligandDOK2, a mediator of downstream signaling from CD200R1 (3/8)

~80% of our 12 million 23andMe customers consent to participate in research & contribute phenotypic dataWe developed an analytical approach, the immuno-oncology (I/O) genetic signature, to identify evidence for genetic variants that ‚¨ÜÔ∏è immune function while ‚¨áÔ∏è cancer risk (2/8)

23andMe initiated a Phase 1 clinical trial for our 1st wholly-owned investigational antibody for treatment of advanced solid tumors23ME-00610 targets CD200R1, which was identified as a promising immuno-oncology target through our Research program (1/8)https://t.co/fYF3mzeaJ1

Exhaustion- idk if it's because my sleep is getting disrupted, because being on physiological high alert wears you out, or both.

Also the occasional racing pulse, which is always fun. But contrary to what movies or whatever would lead you to expect, it's not just when I think about one of the proximate stressors- they can come out of the blue.
My neck feels weirdly tight and my heartbeat really pronounced. It finally clicked that this is my blood pressure being higher than normal.
Nausea- I honestly thought I'd given myself food poisoning, it's been so incredibly intense.

In the middle of a days-long panic attack, and lemme tell you, it's utterly fascinating the range of physical symptoms that something a lot of people brush off as "just in your head" can produce. I'm saying that genuinely as a big ole nerd.

I generally am pretty sincere in my interactions. I don't assume malice unless I have previous expectations that it might be there, something that has always gone absolutely swimmingly in navigating academic politics (/sarcasm)

So now I stop and ask. This means that 1) I run the risk of being seen as out of my depth and unqualified, especially because I'm a queer fem. But also 2) it can get interpreted as me procrastinating or being purposefully difficult.

Then when I only do what I thought the requested change was, it comes across as me being uncooperative or lazy, as doing the bare minimum.But I did what was on the page! It's that there was additional info on a wavelength I completely missed.
This is so normalized that it's not that they're trying to be confusing, but my brain just misses that entirely.

We used regular @illumina EPIC meth arrays to measure 'fluctuating methylation clocks' (FMCs). Applying FMCs revealed surprisingly similar stem cell numbers and dynamics in human colon vs small intestine crypts, despite an order of magnitude difference in #cancer incidence 2/3

Our idea here was to find a set of CpGs that frequently lose or gain methylation & use the meth pattern across those sites as evolving lineage tracing 'barcodes'. A new barcode is introduced each time a CpG site fluctuates its methylation, resolving closely related lineages. 1/3 https://t.co/JA8D6rdj85

Finally, just to repeat a big thank you to everyone who played a part in this (ongoing) effort. And to everyone else, please get involved and send us your feedback! We are excited to hear what you think 9/9

To tackle some of these issues, we plan to host a series of educational webinars on the key aspects of the guidelines and the tools and data needed to interpret these categories of variants. Watch this space for details (when we have them fully worked out...) 8/9

Did I mention our awesome testing group? They painstakingly made their way through a list of 30 variants and gave us really vital feedback! üí™ They also highlighted the difficulty in interpreting variants when the in silico tools and functional assays are unfamiliar. 7/9

Routinely interpreting non-coding region variants will still be a huge challenge for clinical labs for many reasons. We desperately need new tools to help - incl. to visualise tissue specific epigenetic data, and better in silico prediction tools for these variants. 6/9
@j_ellingford did create this awesome figure showing *some* of the non-coding region variant types we do know to cause disease üåü 5/9 https://t.co/3V80IiYOcd

Writing these was challenging - we do not yet know all the mechanisms through which non-coding region variants cause disease. But, we need to start somewhere, and we thought that guidelines that are vague in parts and need to be revised later are better than none at all 4/9

These recommendations are not intended to replace the existing ACMG/AMP guidelines, but rather to sit alongside them and outline adaptations and issues specific to non-coding region variants - for 9 rules we recommend modifications or note extra considerations (in colour üëá) 3/9 https://t.co/MjrivhNgAR

This was a big team effort co-led by the incredible @j_ellingford with input from many others incl. our expert review panel: @joowook, @ProfDBaralle, @EllardSian, David FitzPatrick, @GeneticBill, Jenny Taylor & Steven Harrison and our awesome testing team (huge thanks all)!ü§©2/9

üéâ Excited to start 2022 by sharing our new recommendations for clinical interpretation of non-coding region variants:https://t.co/NF0mmftJ8OWe are posting as a pre-print before journal submission to get your feedback - so please, get interpreting and share your thoughts! 1/9
