Sudarshan is the best-known scientist ever associated with IMSc, and his relations with the institute did ease in later years; he was honoured with a meeting at IMSc for his 80th birthday in 2011. IMSc@60 is a year-long event and there will be space to remember him. 5/5

The turmoil seems to have left a lasting trauma on many from that era. (I was in middle/high school then.) IMSc recovered rapidly in the 1990s to become not just a top-notch research centre, but a place with a fantastic, egalitarian, free-speaking atmosphere to work in. 4/5
Others mentioned Sudarshan in passing, at most. Several spoke about the "turmoil" in the late 1980s, for which Sudarshan is often blamed (but some noted that there were "two sides"). 3/5

One thing that bothered me was relative the lack of mention of ECG Sudarshan in the institute's history. ECG was director for 5 years in the 1980s; the then "joint director" spoke in detail about the institute's expansion in those years, without once mentioning Sudarshan. 2/5

People see genetic counselors for a reason; people have family and loved ones impacted by genetic conditions, folks forgo reproduction out of fear of such conditions. There's a gravitas to these topics that's sometimes missed in discussions I see online and elsewhere.

It seems to me that the problem with broadly downplaying the influence of genetics is that genetic conditions do have a big impact on many folks' lives. Claiming that genetics doesn't determine much isn't a biological fact, but a statement of one's own genetic luck.

Something I struggle with in how we discuss the influence of genetics is that while it's very important to correct excessive and sloppy deterministic thinking, there's an important balance we need to strike that doesn't ignore the experiences of folks with genetic conditions.

To me, mutational spectra alone are grossly insufficient to determine origins, particularly with so few changes.However, their use as evidence should be consistent, and prompts a critical question: If #Molnupiravir DID lead to a new variant, how would we know?4/4

As @WmHaseltine and others have pointed out, the same spectrum is generally consistent with that induced by #Molnupiravir, and South Africa locations were used in drug trials implementing low doses (more likely to cause only sublethal mutagenesis).3/4https://t.co/7tzzMZTJrm

Specifically, this preprint argues for a mouse origin, in part because #Omicron's mutational spectrum (proportion of changes A>C, A>G, A>U, ..., U>G) is similar to that observed when coronaviruses adapt to mouse cells.h/t @AprilWei001 & @GenomeNathan 2/4https://t.co/H5k10UxnP2

The pattern of genetic changes in #Omicron is consistent with a mouse host, interpreted here as evidence of a mouse origin.But the same pattern is also consistent with #Molnupiravir. Should it thus be interpreted as evidence of a drug-related origin?1/4https://t.co/1jXiEuWQNs

Why guide-counter?If you have any experience analyzing CRISPR screens you've almost certainly tried MAGeCK. It's widely used, highly cited and generally works well. Surprisingly though, MAGeCK count is both rather slow and misses counting a non-trivial amount of the data.

guide-counter: faster, more accurate, drop in replacement for MAGeCK count by @tfenne in #Rust #Bioinformatics. Process FASTQs from CRISPR screen experiments to generate a matrix of per-sample guide counts.* Github: https://t.co/QGLOzf2inN* Bioconda: https://t.co/CyXSuPbCuI

Last words - 2 doses of all vaccines will protect against death. The variation is small. Since individual risk is also smaller, this is OK for now, when many are yet to get vaccinated. Those at higher risk- by age, co-morbidity, or exposure- do merit additional doses.

To summarize, molecular and clinical data does show that individual risk from Omicron is lower but society risk remains high. It is not nature's vaccine and while there is no reason for panic, there is a social responsibility to protect ourselves and others - Vaccines and Masks!

Any advice that Omicron does not cause deaths is wrong. The death toll is over a thousand and rising, based on changes from Delta outbreak trajectory. It is still only about a month. Also, it is not only older people with high co-morbidities who have died.

Omicron can sidestep the usual entry pathways and go in via endodomal fusion. It may infect different types of cells than previous. We only have one month of data and we can already see explosive outbreaks with low fraction but high absolute numbers of hospitalizations.

A very useful thread summarizing how Omicron is fundamentally different from previous variants in terms of how and what it infects. While it contains molecular insights into why severe pneumonia is less common, it also contains insights into what makes it a VOC. https://t.co/1F03zoBbw5

The novelty in mRNA vaccines comes from many places, but the idea is incredibly obvious. The difficult part is getting an implementation that actually works, which he absolutely did not do.

So no "the inventor of mRNA vaccines" is not anti vax, because he's not the inventor. He's one of dozens and dozens of people who got the ball rolling on an idea that is basically immediately obvious to anyone who knows the basics of gene expression and immunology.

There's exceptions, (mostly from back when science was a hobby for rich dudes with the time and resources to do it) but basically every major discovery has been the result of many people's incremental advances.
Science is not one person who understands things better than anyone else in a lab having an epiphany and solving the problem the next day.

Don't know about anyone else but when I see antivaxxers talking about "the inventor of mRNA vaccines" being "on their side" it makes me think about how much damage the Hollywood conception of how science is performed does.

Many US labs also submit to @NCBI Genbank and SRA, where US labs have contributed 1,563,380 sequences, not counting wastewater, environmental and other complex sequence datasets.

As we close out 2021, US @GISAID submissions sit at 2,120,529 sequences from >500 teams. This is an increase of over 2M sequences in 2021 alone, and represents coordinated acceleration of genomic surveillance across the country. Together, these data represent 31.8% of @GISAID.

Since its inception #SPHERES has grown from a discussion between a few dozen sequencing groups, to a thriving community and hub for US SARS-CoV-2 sequencing. Today, we're over 1,400 scientists, representing public health and gov, academia, clinical labs and the private sector.
